note: provide stimulating and often controversial introductions to British politics.
title: The Politics of the People in Eighteenth-century Britain
Patrons and Parties: The Unreformed Electoral System of Hanoverian England, 1734–1832

title: The State in Early Modern France

note: Charles Ingrao, The Habsburg Monarchy 1618–1815 (Cambridge, 1994), and T. C. W. Blanning, Joseph II (London, 1994).
title: The Napoleonic Empire
should be consulted. Jonathan Israel, The Dutch Republic: Its Rise, Greatness, and Fall, 1477–1806
is a mine of information. On Germany and the Habsburg Monarchy, see John Gagliardo, Germany under the Old Regime 1600–1790

container-title: Lukowski, Liberty’s Folly: The Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth in the Eighteenth Century
title: On Poland, the most authoritative account is now J

note: On Russia, three distinguished works are Simon Dixon, The Modernisation of Russia 1676–1825
title: The best history of Sweden in the period is Michael Roberts, The Age of Liberty: Sweden, 1719–1772

container-title: Enlightened Absolutism
title: Lindsey Hughes, Russia in the Age of Peter the Great (New Haven
Russia in the Age of Catherine the Great
contains a collection of stimulating essays on an important subject, including good essays on Italy and Spain

note: On Italy, there is Stuart Woolf, A History of Italy 1700–1860: The Social Constraints of Political Change (London, 1979). On the more advanced societies of western Europe, see John Brewer and Roy Porter, Consumption and the World of Goods: Consumption and Society in the Eighteenth Century (London, 1993), and Roy Porter, English
title: An excellent general survey of the nobility is Jonathan Dewald, The European Nobility 1500–1800
More specialized are the articles in H
The European Nobilities in the Seventeenth and Eighteenth Centuries
Controversial but concise and stimulating is Guy Chaussinand-Nogaret, The French Nobility in the Eighteenth Century: From Feudalism to Enlightenment
On the urban world, see Jan de Vries, European Urbanisation 1500–1800
Good on the peasantry are
The Peasantries of Europe: From the Fourteenth to the Eighteenth Centuries
The Peasantry in the French Revolution
The German Peasantry: Conflict and Community in Rural Society from 256 | the eighteenth century the Eighteenth to the Twentieth Centuries
On the large and growing underclass, see Olwen Hufton’s classic study The Poor of 18th Century France
On the peasantry of Russia and much else besides, the standard work is now Janet M. Hartley, A Social History of the Russian Empire 1650–1825
On Germany, see Eda Sagarra, A Social History of Germany 1648–1914

container-title: and a more substantial treatment in Olwen Hufton, The Prospect before her: A History of Women in Western Europe, i. 1500–1800
title: Society in the Eighteenth Century
On gender issues and the role of women, there is an excellent general account in Merry E. Wiesner, Women and Gender in Early Modern Europe

container-title: The Fontana Economic History of Europe, iii.The Industrial Revolution
German original
note: On European agriculture, there is still no general work to rival the magisterial survey by B. H. Slicher van Bath, The Agrarian History of Western Europe, A.D. 500–1850 (London, 1963; Dutch original, 1959). On European industry before the factory, with chapters on most parts of the continent, see Sheilagh Ogilvie and Markus Cerman (eds.), European Proto-Industrialisation
title: The Economy On the pre-industrial European economy, the best general textbook is still Jan de Vries, The Economy of Europe in an Age of Crisis, 1600–1750

which has a particularly good discussion of agriculture in chapter 2. For an up-to-date survey of research over the intervening two decades, engagingly presented, see Robert S. DuPlessis, Transitions to Capitalism in Early Modern Europe
A rare central and east European emphasis is provided in Peter Kriedte, Peasants, Landlords and Merchant Capitalists: Europe and the World Economy, 1500–1800
On the European economies during industrialization, a classical perspective is provided by the chapters by experts on various European economies in Carlo
For an alternative approach, which focuses on regions rather than nation states, see Sidney Pollard, Peaceful Conquest: The Industrialisation of Europe 1760–1970

container-title: The Economic History of Britain since 1700, i. 1700–1860
The British Industrial Revolution: An Economic Perspective
British) Industrial Revolution

container-title: especially the excellent ‘Editor’s Introduction’. On long-distance trade, see Ralph Davis, The Rise of the Atlantic Economies further reading

note: the basic work is J. De Vries, European Urbanisation 1500–1800 (Cambridge, Mass., 1984).
title: An economist’s treatment of finance, which sets the changes of the eighteenth century in the context of developments between the medieval period and the twentieth century, is Charles B. Kindelberger, A Financial History of Western Europe

container-title: The Enlightenment in National Context
Michael Levey, Rococo to Revolution: Major Trends in 18th Century Painting (1966), and Hugh Honour, Neo-Classicism (Pelican, 1968); of architecture, David Watkin, A History of Western Architecture
The Popes and European Revolution (Oxford
note: London, 1996); of music, Neil Zaslaw, Man and Music: The Classical Era. From the 1740s to the End of the Eighteenth Century (London, 1989), and Giorgio Pestelli, The Age of Mozart and Beethoven (Cambridge, 1984). On the baroque, the best introduction is John Rupert Martin, Baroque (London, 1977). The astonishing surge of German cultural activity is described by Victor Lange, The Classical Age of German Literature 1740–1815 (London, 1982). A distinguished introduction to the popular culture of the period is Peter Burke, Popular Culture in Early 258 | the eighteenth century
title: The best general account of religion in the eighteenth century is now W
Christianity during the Old Regime
The World of Catholic Renewal 1540–1770
Church and Society in Eighteenth Century France
On religion during the revolutionary–Napoleonic period, see Owen Chadwick
The Role of Religion in European Counter-Revolution, 1789–1815’
History, Society and the Churches: Essays in Honour of Owen Chadwick
Difficult but rewarding is the immensely influential book by Jürgen Habermas, The Structural Transformation of the Public Sphere: An Inquiry into a Category of Bourgeois Society
A more accessible collection on the same theme is
Habermas and the Public Sphere
On the Enlightenment, the best introduction is Dorinda Outram, The Enlightenment
which has a good bibliography. It should be complemented by
One of the best books on French culture in the period is the unjustly neglected J. Lough, An Introduction to Eighteenth Century France
Dena Goodman’s The Republic of Letters: A Cultural History of the French Enlightenment

is excellent on the social context, stressing especially the crucial role played by women. The best introductions to the visual arts of the eighteenth century are Matthew Craske, Art in Europe 1700–1830
Popular Religion in Germany and Central Europe

container-title: The Rise of the Great Powers
title: The Military Revolution: Military Innovation and the Rise of the West, 1500–1800
is a very important study that set off a virtual industry of works on the military revolution, subject to some criticism but of great value

container-title: Jean-Paul Bertaud, The Army of the French Revolution
note: From Citizen-Soldiers to Instruments of Power (Princeton, 1988), is the finest single volume on the army of revolutionary France. T. C. W.
title: The Wars of Louis XIV, 1667–1714
is the only military history of these wars as a whole available
The War of the Austrian Succession, 1740–1748
is essentially a diplomatic history of this convoluted war, with little military detail. Paul Kennedy, The Rise and Fall of British Naval Mastery
is a good introduction to British naval history, although it extends well beyond this period
Blanning’s two complementary studies The Origins of the French Revolutionary Wars (London, 1986) and The French Revolutionary Wars, 1787–1802
provide a broadly conceived and authoritative diplomatic and military history of these crucial conflicts
The French Revolution in Germany (Oxford, 1983), charts the destructive impact of the French armies and the resistance they encountered

publisher: Paul W. Schroeder, The Transformation of European Politics
title: The Campaigns of Napoleon
is still the best detailed picture of Napoleon as a general, although it should be used with care

container-title: Cambridge History of Latin America
There are valuable chapters on eighteenth-century Spanish and Portuguese America in
title: is the new classic on the history of international relations in this period with a profoundly thought-provoking approach and towers above the rest. Europe and the rest of the world

is a useful general account

container-title: Curtin, The Rise and Fall of the Plantation Complex: Essays in Atlantic History

is an overview. A succinct introduction to the West Indies, the ‘plantation belt’, and the slave trade is Philip D

describe the making of the new British Indian Empire. For the movement of people

Tsar Peter I (‘the Great’) seizes power in Russia

note: John Locke, An Essay Concerning Human Understanding and Two Treatises on Government. 1693–5 First Brazilian gold strike.
title: William III of England defeats James II at the Battle of the Boyne
Bank of England founded
Peter the Great captures Azov from the Turks
Peace of Karlowitz ends war between Austria and the Turks

container-title: Death of Charles II of Spain. chronology
title: Great Northern War begins

publisher: Elector Frederick III of Brandenburg becomes King Frederick I of Prussia
title: Act of Settlement establishing Hanoverian succession in England. War of the Spanish Succession begins
First national daily newspaper founded in England
Peter the Great founds St Petersburg
Battle of Blenheim
Union of England and Scotland
Vauban, Projet d’une dixième royale
Meissen porcelain manufactory established in Saxony
Exterior of the Palace of Schönbrunn completed
Newcomen develops the first commercially successful steam engine (used in coal mines

container-title: The papal bull Unigenitus condemns Jansenism
note: 262 | the eighteenth century
title: Treaty of Utrecht: Britain makes territorial gains in North America and West Indies and acquires the right to supply slaves to Spanish empire

note: 1715 Death of Louis XIV. 1715–16 Failed Jacobite rising in Britain.
title: Treaty of Rastatt ends the War of the Spanish Succession. Death of Queen Anne; succession to the English throne of the Elector of Hanover as George I
War between Austria and the Turks. Corps des Ingénieurs des Ponts et Chaussées begins to develop the French road system to be the finest in Europe
Establishment of the first Grand Lodge in London begins the modern history of Freemasonry
Death of Charles XII; beginning of Swedish ‘Age of Liberty’. Murder of Tsarevich Alexei of Russia. Treaty of Passarowitz ends war between Austria and the Turks
Frederick William I of Prussia establishes the General Directory
Death of Peter the Great. Vico, New Science
St Matthew Passion
Protestants expelled from Salzburg emigrate to Prussia. Holy Roman Empire issues law trying to restrict guild powers (proves largely ineffectual
Voltaire, Lettres philosophiques
War between Russia, Austria, and the Turks
John Wesley’s conversion experience begins the history of Methodism
Beginning of Anglo-Spanish war in Caribbean

author.literal: Deaths of Charles VI, Frederick William I, and the Tsarina Anna.

title: Frederick II invades Silesia; War of the Austrian Succession begins
Treaty of Breslau ends the First Silesian War between Prussia and Austria. 264 | the eighteenth century
Paul’s spinning machine is first used with water power
Treaty of Dresden ends the Second Silesian War between Prussia and Austria
Failed Jacobite rebellion in Britain
French capture Madras; beginning of Anglo-French wars in India

container-title: Dutch republic. Muratori, Of the Well-Ordered Devotion of Christians
title: William IV’s Orangist ‘revolution
Horace Walpole begins the construction of Strawberry Hill. Buffon, Natural History
First volume of the Encyclopédie
Pope grants abolition of fifty-three feast days to help Catholic countries compete with Protestant rivals
Beginning of Anglo-French hostilities in North America, merging after 1756 into worldwide Seven Years War

container-title: Rebuilding of the Benedictine Abbey of Ottobeuren completed
title: Pombal establishes monopoly company for part of Brazil trade. Lisbon earthquake. Winckelmann, Thoughts on the Imitation of the Greeks. chronology | 265 Samuel Johnson, A Dictionary of the English Language
The ‘diplomatic revolution’––i.e. the alliance of France and Austria. Seven Years War begins, as does the Third Silesian War
David Hume, An Enquiry Concerning Human Understanding

note: Jesuits expelled from Portugal. Voltaire’s Candide. British Museum opened.
title: British take Quebec. Battle of Kunersdorf
The village betrothal
Duke of Bridgewater’s canal links the Worsley mines with Manchester

container-title: Expulsion of Jesuits from Spanish empire
title: Serious rioting in Madrid forces Charles III to flee. Louis XV issues rebuke, known as the Flagellation, to the Parlement of Paris
Catherine the Great’s Instructions to the Legislative Assembly
The Royal Academy founded, with Sir Joshua Reynolds as its first president
Histoire philosophique et politique des deux Indes
Maupeou’s revolution remodels French parlements. Pope abolishes another twenty feast days to improve productivity of Catholic countries
Famine in central Europe; potato begins to be widely introduced

publisher: Warren Hastings becomes governor of Bengal
title: Gustav III’s coup ends Swedish ‘age of liberty’. First partition of Poland

publisher: Boston Tea Party. Goethe, The Sorrows of Young Werther
title: Suppression of the Jesuit Order by Pope Clement XIV
Death of Louis XV, accession of Louis XVI, recall of the old parlements. Herder, Another Philosophy of History Concerning the Development of Mankind. Swedish chemist Scheele discovers chlorine
First metalled road built in Prussia
Adam Smith’s The Wealth of Nations is translated into French. 268 | the eighteenth century
British naval victory over the French at the Saintes in the West Indies. French and Spanish siege of Gibraltar fails
Russian annexation of the Crimea

note: Guilds abolished in the Austrian Netherlands (Belgium).
title: 1784 Spanish administrative reforms introduced into Peru. Cort perfects the puddling process for converting pig iron into wrought iron in a reverbratory furnace
The Oath of the Horatii. First Boulton and Watt steam engine is erected in a Belgian coalfield, at Jemappes
Berthollet experiments with chlorine for bleaching cloth
Regency crisis in Britain

container-title: may Meeting of the Estates General. july Fall of the Bastille. aug. Promulgation of the Declaration of the Rights of Man. oct. The royal family and the National Assembly brought to Paris. nov. Expropriation of the Church begins
note: Leblanc invents process for deriving soda from sea salt.

container-title: Burke, Reflections on the Revolution in France
note: Mozart, Cosí fan tutte. 270 | the eighteenth century
title: Death of Joseph II, succeeded by his brother Leopold II. july Civil Constitution of the Clergy
Treaty of Campo Formio ends war between France and Austria
Tennant and Macintosh invent bleaching powder for cloth

container-title: Bonaparte returns from Egypt
title: War between France and Austria resumes; Russia enters the war on the side of Austria; the French are expelled from Italy. oct
Bonaparte seizes power in France. Collapse of Dutch East India Company. First water-driven spinning mule is set up in Saxony

container-title: Friedrich von Hardenberg alias Novalis, Hymns to the Night. Alessandro Volta demonstrates first electric battery
title: Bonaparte defeats the Austrians. Battle of Hohenlinden, Moreau defeats the Austrians
1801 Treaty of Lunéville ends war between France and Austria. 272 | the eighteenth century
1802 Treaty of Amiens
War resumes between France and Britain

note: Bonaparte proclaims himself Emperor Napoleon I, is crowned by the Pope Pius VII. Code Napoléon enacted.
title: Holy Roman Emperor, proclaims himself also Emperor of Austria as Francis I

note: chronology | 273 oct. Prussia declares war on France. oct. Battles of Jena and Auerstedt, Prussia defeated.
title: Napoleon makes his brother Joseph King of Naples. june Napoleon makes his brother Louis King of the Netherlands. july Napoleon reorganizes Germany as the ‘Confederation of the Rhine’. aug. Formal end of the Holy Roman Empire when the Emperor Francis II abdicates and becomes Francis I of Austria

container-title: Fichte, Addresses to the German Nation. Caspar David Friedrich, The Cross in the Mountains. Britain abolishes the slave trade
note: Humphry Davy isolates sodium and potassium from their compounds.
title: Russia rejoins war as Prussia’s ally; indecisive campaign in Poland. june Decisive French victory at Battle of Friedland. july Treaty of Tilsit ends war; France and Russia enter alliance. Portuguese royal family flees to Brazil
Napoleon imposes his brother Joseph as King of Spain; Spanish people rise in revolt, assisted by the British army. Rome occupied by French troops

container-title: oct. Treaty of Schönbrunn ends war between Austria and France. Papal States annexed to France
title: War resumes between France and Austria. may Austrians defeat Napoleon at the Battle of Aspern-Essling. july Napoleon defeats the Austrians at the Battle of Wagram

Napoleon marries the Archduchess Marie Louise, daughter of the Emperor Francis I. Napoleon annexes the Netherlands to France. Napoleon annexes the north-western coast of Germany. Revolts against Spanish rule in Venezuela and Rio de la Plata
Luddite’ machine-breaking riots in Britain
1812 Battle of Salamanca, defeat of French in Spain by army commanded by the Duke of Wellington

container-title: dec. Prussian army under Blücher begins the invasion of France. Colombia declares independence from Spain
title: Treaty of Kalisch between Prussia and Russia. june Wellington defeats the French at Vittoria, prompting King Joseph to flee to France. aug. Austria declares war on France. oct. Napoleon is defeated at the Battle of Leipzig and loses control of Germany
Allies abandon attempt to negotiate with Napoleon and conclude Treaty of Chaumont for wartime and post-war alliance

Wellington captures Bordeaux. apr. Napoleon abdicates, is exiled to the island of Elba; Louis XVIII returned to French throne. sept. General negotiations for a comprehensive peace settlement begin at Vienna. Uruguay declares independence from Spain

container-title: nov. Second treaty of Paris reduces France to frontiers of 1790. Humphry Davy invents miner’s safety lamp. This page intentionally left blank Maps Map 2 Europe in 1789. maps
